docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-5 U.S. Won't Back Measure Criticizing China on Rights The Clinton Administration gave China a boost by dropping American sponsorship of an annual United Nations resolution condemning China's record on human rights. The move effectively kills the resolution. Senior Administration officials said the action was a response to Beijing's recent efforts to bolster its human rights record. A1

headline.main: Cultural Issues Pose Obstacles In Cancer Fight

docs.abstract: Federal health officials say that while African-Americans and other minorities have been slower than whites to benefit from national trend toward drop in new cancer cases and deaths, gaps may be narrowing soon as minorities increasingly take advantage of screening programs; black women are now having mammographies at same rates as white women, trend that began in 1992 (M)4
docs.lead_paragraph: The Breast Examination Center of Harlem was designed as a cheery place, with toys to entertain patients' children and a billing policy as inviting as the atmosphere: mammograms, free of charge. But when the newly expanded center opened four years ago, its doctors were dismayed to discover that the women of Harlem were not banging down the doors to take advantage of their offer. ''We were running way under capacity,'' said Dr. Paul A. Marks, president of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, which runs the Harlem center, ''and it was clearly not a question of cost. It's a mind-set.''

headline.main: Apprentices Sample Life Of Doctors In Villages

docs.abstract: Article discusses medical apprenticeship program created by medical anthropologist David Napier at Middlebury College in Vermont; premed majors at school are enrolled in one month program aimed at showing them realities of country practice; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Stephen Genereaux, a doctor in this remote village, listened to Doris Berry's heartbeat. He instructed his young assistant, Jessie Reynolds, to put up her stethoscope and do the same. Mrs. Berry, who is 90, did not mind the extra set of hands; the examination room was so tiny that the three were already crowded together. ''Just fine, Mrs. Berry,'' Dr. Genereaux said, signaling the end of the exam. But he continued, ''Now, tell Jessie about your horse.''
